where_to_read: IS there any better place to read

reviews.review_text: Nathanael West is best known for his novel The Day of the Locust (1939) which shows the seedy side of trying to make it as an actor in LA. He wrote four short novels, all satirizing the American Dream, but died at age 37 when he ran a stop sign and an oncoming car killed him and his wife (F. Scott Fitzgerald had died just the day before). West penned Miss Lonelyhearts during the grip of the depression, which highlights the sadness and desperation of the times. The protagonist, which West only refers to as “Miss Lonelyhearts,” works as an advice columnist for a newspaper. He receives letters from people dealing with abuse, suicidal thoughts, and all kinds of grim realities he isn’t suited to provide advice for. He slips into a state of depression, has hallucinatory fantasies, and starts sleeping with a woman who writes to him for advice. West creates a gritty and raw world that is realistic yet fantastic, ending with a bang that makes the entire book feel like a dream.I love Nathanael West but feel like I missed something with The Day of the Locust. It's on many "top books about Hollywood," and take place in the 30s, so of course I had to read it, but for as much as it was about the geography and architecture of the city it was also about things like cock fights (which I feel like I never need to read again). I think it does show the seedy underbelly of the city well but I just didn't feel like it really went anywhere.Overall West is worth reading. He gives an insight into 30s America and the bleakness of the depression.
I read this book on recommendation from a radio personality.  The prose is well-written, but it is a rather bizarre story, which I rate as about a C.
I read it thirty years ago and it still holds up. An American classic.
Review is for this version. It feels like it's an accident? Like typos on the first page, it almost seems intentional its so bad but what the intent is I have no idea.

While I didn't read this specific edition, as I had a 1960s copy, I assume the story is the same. I listen to the podcast "You Must Remember This" and it was mentioned as a story about the pitfalls of Hollywood life - I was surprised that I hadn't heard of it before. This is a quick, easy read with strongly allegorical characters exploring the falsity and destructiveness inherent in each of us.  I think this is an important read in American literature because Nathaniel West believed the American Dream is a sham and I feel like this is how a lot of people in our country feel - cheated, bored, lonely with only the catharsis of violence to look forward to.  I would've liked to have read the edition that also has his other book, Miss Lonelyhearts, as I think the two together would've been interesting for comparing the arc of development in in West's theory of the American Dream, as he grew older.
Saw this recommended by Paul Theroux and I am really glad I read it. Not a happy, feel-good read but a darn good book.

Good deal! I would tell my friend about this, he need one. My daughter will love it!  Excellent experience fast shipping and the product is satisfactorily functional for it's intended purpose. great product,exceptional customer service
One of the few books I've ever read twice

summary:
"The Day of the Locust" is the celebrated 1939 novel about the Great Depression, set in Hollywood, California, its over-arching themes dealing with the alienation and desperation of a broad group of odd individuals who exist at the fringes of the Hollywood movie industry. 

In 1998, the Modern Library ranked The Day of the Locust #73 on its list of the 100 best English-language novels of the 20th century. Time magazine included the novel in its list of 100 best English-language novels from 1923 to 2005.
story_arc: The story gets better over time
